I'm not going to tell you the correct answer, because there is no correct answer. This is a classic example of a bias in decision-making, known as the "name-letter effect" or "implicit egotism". Research has shown that people tend to favor individuals whose names share similar letters or sounds with their own name. For example, if your name is John, you may be more likely to choose someone named Jonathan or Jackson over someone named Michael or Emily.
